entry.title: Reusable APIs in SAP Integration Suite : Design Once, Use Everywhere
entry.content:
Introduction

Reusable API  artifacts in SAP Integration Suite ‚Äì Edge Integration Cell are modular, internal-only APIs that encapsulate common cross-cutting concerns such as authentication, transformation, validation, or logging.

Instead of duplicating the same policies across multiple APIs, Reusable API act as centrally managed building blocks that can be invoked by other API artifacts through  a special API Direct adapter.

 Key characteristics:

Internal only: They are not exposed as standalone endpoints.

Policy encapsulation: Common logic like authentication or schema validation is defined once and reused.

Independent lifecycle: They can evolve separately from consuming APIs, supporting cleaner governance and versioning.

Performance-aware: Optimized for low-latency chaining between calling APIs and Reusable API s, with correlation IDs ensuring full traceability.

Consistency & compliance: Authentication policy is enforced uniformly across the execution chain.

Use Cases it Addresses

Reusable API artifacts address several real-world challenges faced by API developers and central security/governance teams:

üîëCentralized Security Enforcement

Instead of configuring authentication and authorization separately in every API, organizations can define a Reusable API  artifact with standard security policies (e.g., OAuth/JWT verification, API key validation, IP allowlist). Any new API simply invokes this artifact, ensuring compliance with enterprise-wide standards and reducing the risk of inconsistent security coverage.

‚öôÔ∏èPolicy Reuse & Reduced Duplication

Enterprises often repeat the same transformations (e.g., XML-to-JSON), validations (e.g., schema checks), or response formatting across multiple APIs. By centralizing these policies into Reusable API  artifacts, teams avoid duplication, simplify maintenance, and accelerate delivery of new APIs.

üìäAuditability & Governance

With traceability built in via correlation IDs, Reusable API  artifacts give central teams visibility into how APIs interact across the execution chain. This is particularly useful in regulated industries where demonstrating uniform enforcement of policies (like logging or data masking) is mandatory.

üöÄAccelerated API Development

Developers can focus on business-specific logic in their APIs while leveraging pre-built Reusable API  artifacts for cross-cutting concerns. This speeds up delivery, ensures consistency, and lowers onboarding time for new API projects.

 Creating and consuming a Reusable API Artifact

   Prerequisites
  • Enable API Management and Cloud Integration capabilities  and 
  • Provision Edge Integration Cell runtime.

After you have setup Edge Integration Cell and enabled both the capabilities mentioned above, you will have option to create API artifact. 

         In a typical organization, two key personas benefit the most from reusable API artifacts in SAP Integration Suite:

  1. Central Security Administrator ‚Äì responsible for defining and enforcing security standards across all exposed APIs. They ensure consistent authentication, authorization, and compliance policies without duplicating effort.
  2. API Developer ‚Äì responsible for designing APIs in Integration Suite, modelling business logic, and creating proxies for backend services. With reusable APIs, they can focus on business functionality while relying on centrally managed security and governance.

Lets create a Reusable API as security administrator persona :

 A security administrator logs in to the Integration Suite tenant and navigates to Design ‚Üí Integrations and APIs, then selects an existing content package to model a Reusable API.

              

Select the Edge Integration Cell runtime profile and proceed to choose the API creation method. Among the four available options, you will notice a new entry: Reusable API.

 

 

Provide the required API details to create a Reusable API .

 

Important to note: A Reusable API artifact does not require a target URL or a virtual host since it is designed for internal invocation only via a calling API  using the API Direct adapter. Therefore, it does not have an externally invokable endpoint.

Once all the details are provided, click on Create to create a Reusable API .

 

The sender adapter in a Reusable API is automatically set to API Direct. This is important because it allows the calling API artifact to invoke the Reusable API internally‚Äîwithout an HTTP endpoint and without external exposure. Now, let‚Äôs add a few security policies like Authentication and Authorization to it.

 

 

 

In addition to security policies, you can add mediation policies to extend functionality. For example:

  • Use a Content Modifier to enrich or adjust the message payload.
  • Configure an External Callout to log data to external services such as Loggly.

With these steps, we‚Äôve modelled a Reusable API that handles authentication and authorization, while also logging transaction details to an external system.

Consuming the Reusable API

Let‚Äôs model a caller API that proxies an external backend while consuming the Reusable API created in the previous steps.

Provide the mandatory details for the caller API.

For a standard API, an Authentication policy is always applied as the first policy by default. However, when consuming a Reusable API that already includes an authentication policy, you should remove the default authentication policy from your calling API. This ensures there‚Äôs no duplication or conflict.

As a boundary condition: The first step in your calling API must be either Authentication policy or a Reusable API with Authentication policy as its first step. This keeps the flow clean, avoids redundant auth checks, and maintains proper execution order.

Now, let‚Äôs add a step to invoke the Reusable API created earlier. As the first step, add the reusable API artifact as a global reference in your caller API, as shown below. 

The Reference dialog will display only the deployed Reusable APIs within a package. If you need to reference multiple reusable APIs, you can add them from different content packages simultaneously.

To consume the reusable API, add a Request-Reply step along with a Receiver System to invoke the reusable API. From the list of adapters, select API Direct only. Since the reusable API already includes an Authentication policy, go ahead and delete the authentication policy from your calling API to avoid duplication.

 

Let‚Äôs click on API Direct to configure the adapter‚Äôs connection details, which enables us to reference the reusable API added earlier as a global reference in this API.

 

Now, let‚Äôs examine the properties associated with the API Direct adapter in detail.

 

 a) Resource :This allows you to associate any added reusable API as a reference to this API.  

 b) Address :A read-only field that displays the basepath of the reusable API added in the Resource section. 

 c) Send Body  :Check this box to send the original request body to the reusable API. This is typically used with   POST, PUT, or PATCH methods, where the request payload must be preserved and forwarded to the reusable     flow. 

 d) Retain Original Body for Next Steps : Select this option to keep the original request body available for use in subsequent steps of your caller API.

 e) Headers

  • Request Header: Enter a pipe-separated list of headers (e.g., Authorization|X-Correlation-ID) to send to the reusable API.
    Use * to send all headers by default.
  • Response Header: Enter a pipe-separated list of headers from the reusable API‚Äôs response that should be merged into the caller API‚Äôs original request headers.
    Use * to receive and merge all response headers by default.

Now we have modelled and consumed a Reusable API into the caller API. Please note that if the Reusable API is not deployed, then you will not be allowed to deploy the caller API referring that Reusable API . Now let‚Äôs deploy the caller API.

As both caller and Reusable APIs are deployed, Lets check the status and also invoke the caller.

Monitor and Message logs

Once APIs are deployed lets navigate to Monitor section to introspect the both Caller and the Reusable APIs under Manage Integration Content.

 

One important point to note about reusable APIs is that, since they don‚Äôt have an external endpoint, the Endpoints section does not display any entry as shown above.

 Let change the log level to Trace for both the artifacts.

Now let me invoke the caller API endpoint via a REST client.

 

Let‚Äôs now check the correlation ID for this transaction in both the caller and reusable API logs ‚Äî they should ideally be the same, ensuring end-to-end traceability.

As you can see, the API was invoked successfully.

If you recall from earlier steps, we modelled the reusable API to provide Authentication & Authorization protection and included a mediation policy to log the correlation ID to the Loggly server.

As you can see, the same correlation ID is also being logged into the Loggly server.
Additionally, you can examine the trace details of the executed steps, which will show that the first step was executed via API Direct, exactly as we modelled in our use case.

 

Similarly, the same Reusable API is referred  to another API artifact by the API developer to leverage the centrally defined security and common tasks by administrator.

If a new traffic management policy like Surge protection policy is to be added to all the APIs then API administrator only needs to it to the Reusable API and it will be automatically applied to all the APIs referring the Reusable API.

Points to remember:

  1. At least one authentication policy is mandatory in complete chain including the caller API and Reusable API.
  2. Only Authentication policy or a request reply step to Reusable API can be added as first step in a valid caller API.
  3. A caller API can refer more than one Reusable API, but one Reusable API cannot refer another Reusable API.
  4. Only deployed reusable APIs can be added to the caller API.

Summary

Reusable API artifacts in SAP Integration Suite bring clarity and efficiency to API management. By separating centralized enforcement from API development activities, organizations can achieve both governance and agility. The administrator gains confidence that policies are consistently applied, while the API developer can focus on delivering business value without reinventing the wheel for every project.

In short, reusable APIs strike the right balance between control and productivity, making them a cornerstone for scalable, enterprise-grade API strategies.

entry.title: Re: Streams in RAP : Uploading PDF , Excel and Other Files in RAP Application
entry.content:
Hi,
@RadhikaKuthiala 
@sandhyad 
@Mahiba 

When uploading a file via a child association(Line Items on Root Object Page) in an OData V4 service,
the error Entity set '' not found (/IWBEP/CM_V4_MED015) appears.

This only happens when accessing the attachment field through the parent entity (ROOT).
Uploading directly via the child service works fine,
and the file is then also visible through the parent as expected.

Solution:

I extended the object page of the ROOT entity,
and overrode the client-side upload function to redirect the file upload directly to the child entity's service.
This avoids the "Entity set not found" error and ensures successful uploads.

Code Snippet (Controller Extension):

sap.ui.define(['sap/ui/core/mvc/ControllerExtension',
    'sap/m/MessageToast'
], function (ControllerExtension, MessageToast) {
    'use strict';

    return ControllerExtension.extend('studentapp.ext.controller.StudentObjectPage', {
        override: {
            /**
             * Called when a controller is instantiated and its View controls (if available) are already created.
             * Can be used to modify the View before it is displayed, to bind event handlers and do other one-time initialization.
             * @memberOf studentapp.ext.controller.StudentObjectPage
             */
            onInit: function () {
                this.getInterface().fixBugEntitySetNotFound();
            },

        },

		/*
			changes upload url 
		    From : "/sap/opu/odata4/sap/zhr_sb_student_v4/srvd/sap/zhr_sd_student/0001/ZHR_C_STUDENT_APP(parentKeys...)/_StudentAttachments(childKeys...)/Attachment"
			To:    "/sap/opu/odata4/sap/zhr_sb_student_v4/srvd/sap/zhr_sd_student/0001/ZHR_C_STUDENT_ATTACHMENTS(childKeys...)/Attachment"
		*/
        fixBugEntitySetNotFound: function () {

            if (!sap.ui.unified.FileUploader.prototype._bUploadOverwritten) {

                sap.ui.unified.FileUploader.prototype._bUploadOverwritten = true;
                var fOrignalUpload = sap.ui.unified.FileUploader.prototype.upload;
				
                sap.ui.unified.FileUploader.prototype.upload = function (bPreProcessFiles) {

                    /* Extend - Begin */
                    var sParentService = "ZHR_C_STUDENT_APP", //root service
                        sChildService = "ZHR_C_STUDENT_ATTACHMENTS", //child service
                        sChildAssociation = "_StudentAttachments",
                        sUrl = this.getUploadUrl(),
                        sNewUrl = "";

                    if (sUrl.includes(sParentService) &&
                        sUrl.includes(sChildAssociation)) {

                        sNewUrl = sUrl.split(sParentService)[0] + sChildService + sUrl.split(sParentService)[1].split(sChildAssociation)[1]
                        this.setUploadUrl(sNewUrl)
                    }
                    /* Extend - End */

                    fOrignalUpload.apply(this, arguments);

                };
            }
        }
    });
});


Best Regards,
Ben.

entry.title: Re: Manual Cheque Number Assignment for Outgoing Payments
entry.content:
@silambarasan_RS 

Dedicated Manual Lot: Create a separate cheque lot (e.g., MANUAL_CHQ) with Number Assignment = External. Do not mix internal and external assignments in the same lot. This provides clarity and prevents errors.

Duplicate Prevention: The system will not stop you from entering a duplicate cheque number if you use external assignment. You must have a rock-solid internal process (e.g., a physical logbook or a control spreadsheet) to track which cheque numbers have been used to prevent duplicates.

Security and Controls: Access to transaction FCHI and FPM2 should be restricted to authorized finance personnel due to the risk of duplicate entries and the potential for fraud.

Testing: Always test this configuration thoroughly in your development (DEV) or quality (QAS) system before implementing it in production. Create a test cheque lot and process a few manual and automatic payments to ensure the behavior is as expected.

entry.title: Re: Automatic Posting to Account Foreign exchange gain re...
entry.content:
@Dasun_T 

You thought the forex loss would be 237,094.42 and recorded that expense.

When the transaction finished, the real loss was only 164,142.29.

SAP automatically reverses the extra expense you recorded by booking an income of 72,952.13. This corrects your books to reflect the true, final loss of 164,142.29.

The total P&L impact is now correct: 237,094.42 (Loss Expense) - 72,952.13 (Gain Income) = 164,142.29 (Net Loss), which matches the actual cash difference.

entry.title: Re: Old Supplier invoice not created with reference to in...
entry.content:
In S/4HANA Cloud, there is no standard EDI output automatically triggered for Accounts Payable invoices at the time of posting. However, I would like to kindly share an alternate solution supported in the system:

  • Payment Advice via Output Parameter Determination: You can configure automatic remittance/payment advice as an outbound document. In Output Parameter Determination, select Payment Advice and maintain rules for channel (example, Email) and recipient (supplier BP e-mail). During payment runs, the system automatically issues the remittance advice, which can be sent directly to the supplier or routed through middleware to be converted into an EDI message.
    This is the most commonly used and fully standard approach.

I hope this additional information helps you in your query. 

Thank you so much. 
Kind Regards,
Iza

entry.title: Issue with several fields referencing the same object in a HANA Star Join
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am struggling with making a HANA Calculation view in HANA Cloud (built using the HANA Artefact tools in Business Application Studio), where my information cube includes a reference to the same dimension in several columns. The simplified example is as follows:

A table of Business Partners consisting of ID and Name. For this I have made a Dimension view named "BusinessPartner" consisting of a "Business Partner ID" and "Business Partner Name" column.

A table of Sales Orders consisting of ID, SellerID and BuyerID, the latter both being references to a record in the Business Partner table. For this I have made a Cube view.

Lastly, I want to add the "BusinessPartner" dimension to the Start Schema at the top. Once as "Seller" and once as "Buyer". This is the seemingly trivial scenario I am not able to accomplish. I am running into the following challenges

  • I cannot bring the same Dimension view into the Cube more than once (which I can overcome by creating synonyms)
  • Regardless of me changing the Label Aliases, the dimension still comes out as "Business Partner" (I need it to be "Seller" and "Buyer").

The only way I have so far been able to get the desired end result (the "Seller" and "Buyer" dimensions showing to the end user in Analytics Cloud) is to create a Dimension View for each purpose the referenced object has (i.e. no generic "BusinessPartner" dimension but instead one "Seller" dimension and one "Buyer" dimension). While I am getting the right end result that way, it becomes a nightmare to build and maintain all those dimension views where the only difference is their labels.

I hope the issue is clearly described and that somebody can put me on the right track. Thanks!

//Carl

entry.title: Re: SAP IBP:Disaggregation at two levels
entry.content:
Hi BKREDDY,

As IBP allows only one logic of disaggregation in one KF, you will have to create two different key figures:

1. Requirements -> Req. at Group Plan ( Disagg by Grade%)

2. Req. at Group Plan -> Req. at Next level (Disagg by Count%)

Hope this helps.

Regards,

Rahul Mohnot

entry.title: The Procurement Monthly - September 2025
entry.content:
Summary

This months report focuses on the strategic transformation of procurement and accounts payable (AP). Lots of research covering AI including deploying AI-powered orchestration, elevating procurement from tactical operations to strategic business partnership, with a focus on integrated data, governance, and human-in-the-loop decision-making. AI adoption accelerates spend analysis, supplier collaboration, automation, and compliance, but practical barriers persist‚Äîlegacy systems, fragmented data, and organizational silos.

A review shows that next-generation procurement leaders prioritize resilience, sustainability, innovation, and supplier enablement, positioning modern AP and contract management as essential drivers of financial performance and business agility

Procurecon

Two procurement reports from Procurement, one sponsored by GEP about orchestration and the other by ProcureAbility about AI adoption. As they cover some of the same topics, ive combined the analysis.

GEP's report paints an expansive future where procurement evolves from functional process to strategic orchestrator. With 90% of leaders facing increasing complexity, the solution lies in comprehensive AI-powered orchestration spanning intake management, end-to-end source-to-pay, and cross-domain integration. The vision is compelling: agent-based architectures converting user intentions into automated subtasks, natural language interactions replacing complex interfaces, and procurement professionals freed from tactical work to focus on strategic value creation.

ProcureAbility's research grounds this vision in current reality. While 92% express satisfaction with AI solutions, the implementation story is more nuanced. Most organizations (59%) use AI tactically for specific initiatives rather than comprehensive integration, with 90% lacking confidence in measuring ROI. Despite strong investment intentions (88% increasing spending), challenges around proven examples and change resistance persist.

Both reports agree on fundamental shifts: procurement's democratization (40% of sourcing by non-procurement staff by 2027), the primacy of data analytics investments (70% prioritizing by 2030), and AI's role in supplier management and spend analysis. The success metrics align too ‚Äì cost savings, sustainability improvements, and operational efficiency lead realized benefits.

However, the reports differ on readiness. GEP's orchestration vision assumes organizations can leap to comprehensive AI integration, while ProcureAbility's suggests most remain in moderate implementation phases. This gap between vision and reality reflects the classic technology adoption curve ‚Äìsuccess stories drive ambitious roadmaps, but broader adoption faces practical hurdles.

Beroe ‚Äì AI report

According to the report, the strategic role of AI in  Procurement is now expected to deliver strategic value‚Äîcost savings, risk mitigation, supply resilience, ESG impact‚Äînot just transactional efficiency. However, legacy systems and fragmented data block progress. Success therefore depends on three pillars: Data Excellence (harmonised, contextual, trusted data), Intelligent Recommendations (contextual, prioritised insights versus static reports), and Simplicity and Relevance (role-specific, accessible information).

The report cautions that not all AI is equal. Tasks like invoice matching best suit rules-based AI, while forecasting and risk modelling need predictive or generative AI. Human judgment remains central; AI augments, not replaces, professional decision-making.

The report suggest to start with real, high-impact decision problems. Assess and close data gaps. Prioritise early wins with well-defined use cases and build from pilots to scale, always embedding AI into user workflows and maintaining human-in-the-loop governance.

Barriers and Enablers: Data readiness, explainable AI, change management, integration with existing tools, and a shift from deterministic to probabilistic thinking are all critical for success. Governance and transparency build user trust

F5 - State of AI Application Strategy Report 2025

While 96% of organizations are experimenting with AI, only 2% are ‚Äúhighly ready.‚Äù Most are ‚Äúmoderately ready,‚Äù with AI present in about one-third of applications, used in pockets not end-to-end. Readiness depends on generative/agentic AI deployment, application diversity, model diversity (mix of paid/open-source models), penetration % of apps using AI, and formal practices like data labelling. High readiness means broad, well-orchestrated integration.

Moderately Ready Organizations:

  • Generative AI and AI agents in production, but immature in governance/security and lacking orchestration.
  • Tactics: Using both paid and open-source models for flexibility; starting to deploy AI firewalls and advanced data protection; adopting AI in analytics, security, and customer experience.

Barriers to High Readiness: Siloed use cases, inconsistent policies, security concerns, especially around data use and third-party risks. Low-readiness orgs often lack skilled resources and strategy to move from pilots to scaled execution.

Comparison

As these two reports came out in the same month, there are some consistent themes:

Implications for Procurement Leaders

AI is a Strategic Partner, Not a Silver Bullet: Both reports stress that AI must be applied purposefully, integrated across processes, and always with data readiness and governance front of mind‚Äîespecially given regulatory, risk, and supply chain complexity.

From Reporting to Decision Support: Move away from static dashboards to proactive, explainable recommendations and scenario simulation. AI should guide ‚Äúwhat to do next‚Äù rather than just reporting ‚Äúwhat happened‚Äù.

Collaborative Human-AI Models: Maintain a ‚Äúhuman-in-the-loop‚Äù paradigm, where procurement professionals validate, explain, and direct AI recommendations. This both builds adoption and avoids ‚Äúblack-box‚Äù pitfalls

Comparison: Agreements and Contrasts

 

Beroe: Real Decisions

F5: AI Strategy 2025

AI‚Äôs Role

Augmenting, not replacing, human decisions; domain focus

Core infrastructure, not a feature; operational focus 

Readiness Definition

Data excellence, integrated recommendations, simplicity

Orchestrated, broad app/model integration, formal governance 

Tech Adoption Path

Real-world use cases ‚Üí pilots ‚Üí scale, always with HITL

Model diversity, security, broad use ‚Üí mature into platform 

Key Barriers

Fragmented data, lack of explainability, trust

Siloed deployments, poor orchestration, insufficient governance 

Success Factors

Fit-for-purpose AI, role-tailored insights, continuous feedback

Hybrid AI models, formal data labelling, security/observability 

Governance Themes

Human-in-the-loop, explainability, transparency

Data governance, labelling, firewalls, compliance 

 

SSON State of Ap 2025

The report highlights AP‚Äôs shift from a cost centre to a strategic driver, underpinning cash flow, compliance, and supplier relationships.

Top Challenges: Manual data entry, invoice matching errors, compliance complexity, and increased fraud risk are leading concerns. Only 10% feel ‚Äúvery equipped‚Äù for e-invoicing compliance. This emphasises the complexities of e-invoicing mandates (CTC), global tax/regulation, and advanced fraud risks. The report also highlights the need for integrated, modular platforms and proactive partnership with IT and vendors.

Key metrics include touchless invoice processing rate, invoice processing time, invoices processed per FTE, cost per invoice, and late payment rate. These are strategic levers for AP excellence, focused on automation and cost control.

AP teams are adopting AI for touchless processing, fraud detection, and vendor inquiries, but most are in early phases‚Äîless than 5% have reached high (>70%) automation levels

Ardent Partners State of e-payables 2025

This report which is a staple of the research community, tracks AP‚Äôs evolution from paper-pushing to insight-driven operation over two decades. COVID-19 accelerated adoption of e-Payables but paper invoices persist (>40%) and shows that Best-in-Class AP departments achieve $2.65 per invoice cost and 2.9 days per invoice cycle (vs. $12.42 and 13.5 days ‚ÄúAll Others‚Äù). Exception rates, touchless processing, and supplier enablement are critical differentiators.

The report states that the key priorities are the need to deploy comprehensive e-Payables solutions, improving analytics/reporting, and supplier enablement are top priorities. Supplier participation is identified as the ‚ÄúAchilles heel‚Äù for digital transformation. Best-in-Class AP teams have much higher adoption rates of automated routing/workflow (80%), e-Invoicing (79%), e-Payments (77%), and tend to use integrated payment networks.

AP‚Äôs strategic involvement in cash management, supplier management, and business intelligence is growing but uneven. Collaboration with procurement and treasury is essential for resilience (e.g., managing tariffs, payment timing, supply risk).

44% use AI today; 75% expected to within 12 months. Main objective is increased automation, but secondary priorities include forecasting, cost reduction, and stakeholder satisfaction.

Both the SSON and Ardent Partners 2025 reports position accounts payable (AP) as a critical, evolving function‚Äîmoving from manual, transactional activity to an intelligent, value-generating hub within enterprises.

Comparison & Contrast.

Both reports stress the importance of tight alignment between procurement and AP for supplier enablement, payment optimization, and strategic sourcing. Procurement must partner with AP to drive spend visibility, compliance, and process innovation

Both agree that AP must transform into a strategic partner for procurement, finance, and the broader enterprise, and that success hinges on automation, intelligent analytics, supplier enablement, and compliance.

Both stress that AI adoption and modern e-Payables technologies will accelerate AP‚Äôs strategic contribution in the next 2‚Äì3 years, but acknowledge both barriers and opportunities remain

Area

SSON: State of Accounts Payable 2025

Ardent Partners: State of e-Payables 2025

Commonality

Difference

Strategic AP Role

Value centre, unified payment, embedded AI, continuous improvement

Insight hub, process control, spend/cash management, AI as enabler

Elevating AP to strategic, proactive function

SSON stresses compliance/fraud/data quality; Ardent focuses on benchmarks and transformation maturity

Technology Adoption

Unified payments, touchless automation, modular platforms, phased approach

Comprehensive e-Payables, straight-through processing, payment networks, supplier enablement

Automation and integration drive efficiency and quality

SSON highlights touchless invoice challenges with non-PO invoices; Ardent quantifies automation maturity

AI & Analytics

Machine learning and AI for fraud, query handling, translation

AI for automation, forecasting, cost reduction; new metrics CAIT/SPOR

AI as future driver, but adoption is early

Ardent provides deeper metrics and analytics frameworks

Supplier Enablement

Centralized data, portals, feedback loops, high e-invoice adoption

Identifies supplier enablement as Achilles heel, calls for greater digital onboarding

Supplier participation key to transformation

SSON offers best practices; Ardent quantifies enablement gaps and solutions

Compliance & Risk

Proactive, embedded compliance for global mandates; layered fraud strategy

Compliance aligns with e-Invoicing, spend analytics; fraud prevention partnered with audit/IT

Compliance is central, fraud risk is rising

SSON more granular on regulation frameworks, e-invoicing challenges

 

North Carolina procurement and supply chain study

The latest NCSU study finds procurement and supply chain leaders are finally converging on shared strategic goals, but old operational silos haven‚Äôt vanished yet. Resilience, quality compliance, and sustainability now overshadow traditional cost and delivery metrics, reflecting the need to thrive amid ongoing disruption. Despite strategic alignment, execution gaps persist and can cost businesses dearly through slow decisions, increased risks, and missed opportunities for supply chain performance.

The report states that orchestration‚Äîcoordinating people, processes, and tech has emerged as the practical fix for these gaps. The study shows workflow efficiency and cost savings are the top metrics organizations use to measure orchestration‚Äôs ROI. However adoption faces challenges: data quality, security concerns, and skills gaps stand out as the biggest of them.

The report states that leaders should prioritize cross-functional collaboration on risk and financial outcomes, invest in orchestration technology, pilot AI in key areas, and balance technical solutions with human readiness.

World Commerce and Contracting  - Contract Management

This report ‚ÄúContract Management: An Overlooked Driver of Business Agility and Financial Performance‚Äù spotlights a hidden source of value erosion for organizations: dysfunctional contract management practices. The research reveals that businesses lose an average of 9% annual value due to poor contracting, with top-performing organizations limiting losses to 3%, while the worst experience up to 15% erosion. Procurement leaders are urged to examine how fragmented, slow, and rigid contracts undermine agility and financial outcomes.

The report points out recurring structural issues: siloed processes across Legal, Procurement, Finance, inconsistent skills among contract practitioners, and severe data fragmentation‚Äîcontract data is scattered over an average of 24 separate systems. 83% of executives state contracts are too rigid to adapt during market shifts, directly impacting resilience and speed.

Effective contract management enables faster responses to disruption, operational alignment, and better exploitation of technologies like AI. The report‚Äôs roadmap to maturity encourages organizations to unlock competitive advantage and financial performance by treating contracting as a strategic enabler rather than a bureaucratic hurdle

Insights from CPO‚Äôs

Ahead of DPW in October this year, DPW released an e-book from DPW Amsterdam 2024 which has five leading Chief Procurement Officers to share actionable strategies shaping the next era of procurement.

Iris van den Harst (Equans Netherlands) urged starting small‚Äîfocusing sustainability efforts with top-impact suppliers and industry alignment to standardize requests, which builds rapid credibility and measurable change. Shashi Mandapaty (Johnson & Johnson) frames procurement‚Äôs evolution as indispensable to corporate growth, advocating for supplier innovation, data stewardship, and an unyielding ‚Äúno trade-off‚Äù mindset to create universal value across customers, employees, suppliers, and communities.

Modernizing procurement‚Äôs operation is another recurring theme. Sopan Shah (IHG Hotels & Resorts) recommends aligning tech with business strategy, leveraging new digital tools, and fostering cultures that allow experimentation and intelligent risk-taking. Klaus Staubitzer (Siemens) shows how embedding resilience across multi-tier supply chains and scaling pilots with clear KPIs turns procurement into a value-driving partner, while ensuring that AI initiatives genuinely support human expertise.

Fannie Boulanger (Airbnb) flips compliance-led procurement on its head, showing how culture-first leadership, speedy category strategy, and branding of procurement as a service transform stakeholder buy-in, especially during hypergrowth.

For procurement leaders, these lessons mean building innovation-centric teams, investing strategically in data and tech that empower‚Äînot replace‚Äîhuman judgment, and making procurement a central force for sustainable business impact

As always reach out to discuss more, and always happy to hear your thoughts!

entry.title: Re: Keine Berechtigung in Finanzen und Recht - Lizenznutzung
entry.content:
Hi Markus,

To access the Private Cloud Consumption card within the Finance & Legal - SAP for Me, it is necessary for an S-user to have the specific authorization called 'Access License Utilization for Private Cloud'. Upon reviewing your S-user ID, I noticed that your current permissions do not include this required authorization. Typically, when an S-user lacks this authorization, they need to reach out to their Super Administrator to have it granted. 

In order to resolve this problem, I have manually adjusted the permissions for your S-user ID as you are the Super Administrator but do not have the necessary authorization. You should now be able to access the Private Cloud Consumption card without any difficulties.

For additional details, please refer to the following KBAs:

3440820 - Data not loading in Consumption application - SAP for Me

2981882 - S-user ID authorization requirements - SAP for Me

If you encounter any further challenges or have additional questions, please don‚Äôt hesitate to let me know. 

Best regards,
SAP Support

Dear SKAE,

I see that we are implementing 4X9. As per below please see if the steps as per set up guide.

https://me.sap.com/processnavigator/SolS/EARL_SolS-013/2508/SolP/4X9?region=DE

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/2dcf49a616b842b096e0a3cad4dac458.html 

This app calls the Document Information Extraction service to extract data from purchase order files. Currently, the app supports purchase orders in English or German (see Supported Languages (Base Edition)). You do not need to have an enterprise account on SAP Business Technology Platform (which requires a separate license) to use the service.

1. Open the Intelligent Scenario Management app (business role SAP_BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST), and search
for intelligent scenario SO_AUTO_EXTRACTION.
2. Within the intelligent scenario, choose the default version.
3. On the Deployments tab, activate the default deployment for all.
ÓÅú Note

SD-SLS-IMP-DOX.

Regards

Sahil Grover

entry.title: Re: Table TOBJ list of authorization EHP8
entry.content: Hello @manthana99c17, SU25 is the way how to apply changes done by patch, SAP Note, upgrade, into your roles. In case of too much changes I guess it could be splitted directly using Step 2a - at first only for standard SAP space, including all steps as usually. Then it could be runned again, only for customer applications in customer space, all steps as above. Sometimes upgrade, SAP Note, patching brings no changes in authorization, sometimes yes. You can run SU25 every day but it will display only changes in authorizations in impact of installations on application level. No installation, no change üòÅ Regarding auto update from SAP system, you mean regular maintenance proceeded on SAP system in SAP Cloud? As we are currently running S/4 conversion and moving our SAPs into SAP RISE Cloud, a final procedure how to deal with is not established yet. But thanks to your question, the first check using table/s USOBX* to see if anything has changed sounds like a good idea. If you will not run SU25, no changes would be applied into roles. It means if EHP8 would bring new auth object/s, new default values, or removal of any auth object/s, etc., for your roles this change will exist only after SU25. Of course, you can check if is needed, if any change has been caused, it's on you. But if changes with an impact to authorization happen, until SU25 finished, they can cause strange auth error/s. BR, Olga

entry.title: Re: set the condition rate using the attributes sent from...
entry.content: When using the CRM_COND_COM BADI to modify condition values in CRMD_ORDER, the BADI is designed to execute on save, not on a simple 'Enter' key press. The IPC (Internet Pricing and Configurator) executes more frequently, including on 'Enter.' The issue you're facing is a timing and data synchronization problem. Your BADI logic runs on save, updating a value, but the IPC re-calculates before this change is fully processed and communicated back to it. Consequently, the IPC's pricingCondition object doesn't have the updated value from your BADI when it performs its calculation, leading to the condition rate not changing. To correctly change the condition rate, the modification must be handled within the IPC userexit itself, using the data passed to it, or by ensuring the data is available to the IPC before its calculation step. The pricingCondition.setConditionRate() method is the correct way to change the value within the IPC, but it must be provided with the correct, updated data at the time of execution.

entry.title: Re: e-Doc Submission Error from SD Module Due to Missing...
entry.content: Check the Configuration in Table EDOCOMPANYACTIV Go to transaction SE16N or SM30 and open the table EDOCOMPANYACTIV. Verify the document types configured for your company code and country (Turkey). Ensure that SD_INVOICE is listed and active for Turkey. Update the Source Document Type In your SD billing process or e-Document configuration, replace SD_INVNOAC with SD_INVOICE. This change ensures compatibility with the Turkish Revenue Administration (GIB) integration. Adjust the e-Document Cockpit Settings Go to EDOC_COCKPIT and check the document type mappings. Make sure that the correct document type (SD_INVOICE) is used for Turkey. Test the Flow Again After updating the document type, reprocess the export document. Ensure the discharge date and other mandatory fields are populated before sending.

entry.title: Re: Data Extraction from S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello @Germaine 

Thank you for your question. Below are possible ways to achieve your Data extraction

You can consider the following options:

  1. You can build custom CDS Views in S/4HANA Cloud to expose the fields you need for export. See  Data Extraction options. The options cover master data and transactional data EXTRACTING DATA FROM SAP S/4HANA CLOUD USING THE CUSTOMER DATA RETURN APP
  2. SAP provides an Attachment API in Public Cloud to retrieve files  Manage attachments using this synchronous inbound service. You can also consult the Fiori App Library.
  3. You also have the option to extract data using tools like SAP Data Intelligence, ETL tools, middleware platforms and cloud data platforms. These can be combined with the custom CDS/OData endpoints. Also you can use the Customer Data Return App. EXTRACTING DATA FROM SAP S/4HANA CLOUD USING THE CUSTOMER DATA RETURN APP AND TRANSFERRING IT

There are some limitations you should be aware of. To achieve what is described in those steps, you have to ensure the right communications arrangement / API authorisations are in place. Attachments API may also be a limitation due to size. Also considering you want to export large data, this can lead to performance issues.

Here is my recommendation summarised

To ensure smooth extraction, ensure you define scope, use the CDS views to expose all needed master data, used attachment API or script to download them in batches, set up scripts or use ETL tools (e.g., SAP Data Intelligence), ensure your data is complete so you don‚Äôt miss anything and finally organise your data or files in a repository with metadata.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: CDS Table Entity
entry.content:
What is CDS Table Entity? 

A CDS Table entity defines a database table in ABAP CDS as an ABAP-managed database object. 

Table entities are like a special container that provide a persistence layer for ABAP applications. 

 It supports CDS associations, semantic meta data with CDS annotations and typing with both CDS simple types and CDS enumerated types. 

Advantages  

> By using CDS table entity we can perform the CRUD (Select, update, modify, delete) operations and also it can be used as a data type in ABAP. 

>CDS entities as the active persistence layer in scenarios with or without draft capabilities. 

>When you're building a business object (like something that handles customer orders or travel bookings), you need a place to store its data permanently. You can do this by using table entities, which act like real database tables. This setup makes sure your business object's data is saved and managed, so it‚Äôs always available when needed. 

>We can also control who can read the data in these tables by setting access rules, so only the right people can see sensitive information. 

>It helps you organize data by showing how different parts are connected‚Äîlike building a tree structure where one item is the parent and others are children. This is called a composition tree, and it helps model complex relationships in your data. 

 >Annotations at the element level can be used to add semantic information, such as text labels.  

Disadvantages  

>Table entities are not supported for draft persistence as of now. The reason is that currently include structures are not supported for table entities, which prevents including a draft admin include required for RAP draft tables. 

>Extending table entities is currently not supported. 

>Currently, CDS table entities cannot be used in ABAP analytics for building analytical data models, such as cubes and dimensions. They can't be enabled for data-extraction. 

 Defining table Entities 

Let‚Äôs take a look at the delightful syntax that brings a table entity to life!" 

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 

@EndUserText.label: 'Table Entity' 

@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass: #APPLICATION_DATA 

@ClientHandling.type: #CLIENT_INDEPENDENT 

define table entity Entity_Name 

{ 

    [field] 
    [association] 

} 

üåüLet‚Äôs light up the concept with a hands-on example! 

We can create a Table Entity with key or without key field as well. 

Without Key field  

  

üåüIn this example, we‚Äôll be creating a table entity featuring a key field to uniquely identify each record.             

                                           

üí°Before we dive into performing CRUD operations in this class, there's an important note to highlight: we‚Äôll be using a specific interface IF_OO_ADT_CLASSRUN that contains a dedicated method main for executing these operations. While it's technically possible to perform the actions without it, using this interface ensures that the output is properly displayed in the console.

‚ö†Ô∏èTo ensure smooth execution of the class, it's essential to implement the IF_OO_ADT_CLASSRUN interface. Without it, the system will display the message below.                                                   

‚ú®Now, let‚Äôs build a class that handles CRUD operations seamlessly using our CDS table entity.                 

   

üöÄNext, we‚Äôll proceed with inserting records into the CDS table entity to demonstrate its functionality in action. 

                                              

Output: 

We can see the output in console

üîçLet‚Äôs now perform the read operation and retrieve the records we just inserted into the CDS table entity. 

Output:

üåü"Let's proceed with the update operation and retrieve the records to review the changes. Similarly, we can perform modifications as needed!"

Output:

üåü"Let's move on to the final step‚Äîperforming the delete operation and retrieving the records to confirm the changes!" 

Output:

Quick Recap üß†

CDS Table Entities offer a powerful way to define and manage persistent data in ABAP applications. They support CRUD operations, semantic annotations, and complex data modeling through composition trees. While they‚Äôre not yet compatible with draft persistence or analytics, they remain a key building block for structuring business objects in ABAP.

üí¨If you‚Äôve got thoughts, questions, or experiences with CDS Table Entities, feel free to drop them in the comments‚ÄîI‚Äôd love to hear how you're using them in your ABAP projects.

entry.title: Safe quantities in orders from being rescheduled?
entry.content:
Hello,

I am new to this community, so apologies already if my questionning is kinda vague, since I am also not very much into the technical things either üôÇ

However, since I am stuck within all the ressources that I have to find a solution, I am now reaching out to you.

Every night we have a job running called "rescheduler" which assigns quantities of products anew, according to priorities, but also to delivery date. So, for example it takes the product quantities from one order that has the delivery date set for 30.11. and adds them to an order with a delivery date 22.11. (even though this order was received already wayyy earlier). While this is quite nice for products that come regularly on stock, this is not so nice for products that are presold, where we rather require a first come, first serve setting (or even exit products).

So, I am wondering if there is any setting in SAP (maybe directly in the orders or with the article) that protects them from being touched by the "rescheduling"?

Any idea on this would be highly appreciated.

Thank you and best regards

Dietmar

entry.title: Re: Formula Calculation of 'Best Possible' DSO
entry.content:
Hi @12345678901 

Thank you for your question to the community. Let me walk you through the points you raised.

On your first point, you do not need to add another app to display Best possible DSO. It is already available in the average DSO app. However, this only appears when the underlying calculation can be derived. So, if you only see actual DSO, then it means the filters or data conditions for the best possible DSO are not met.

On your second point, sample filter setup to replicate Best possible DSO calculation. Open Manage Customer Line Items app, apply the filter Your Cocd to your company code √†for the status choose Open Items √†Open Key date to last day of reporting period √† Item type: normal items + special G/L transactions √†adapt filters: journal entry √† journal entry category √† normal document.

Finally, make sure to export or aggregate your total open receivables.

Please reference Days Sales Outstanding  link for more details.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: A better way to create the Root-Child-Grandchild hierachy in RAP
entry.content:
The RAP Framework supports Parent - Child - Grandchild - Great Grandchild - and so forth.

There are beautiful blog posts on how to do this:

  • How to design managed RAP business objects with 3 or more levels of nodes : Shows the basic idea.
  • Create Root-Child-Grandchild-Great Grandchild relationship using RAP : Shows the actual implementation.

Both of them relies on storing a reference to the root in each and every descendant. As in: a child has a reference to the parent, and a grandchild (or great grandchild) has a reference to the root parent as well.

This is required so that in the Behavior Definition of each descendant, the association to the root can be used for `lock` and `authorization`.

But this has got me thinking: Why do we have to store the reference to the root in each descendant like this? Couldn't we do something like:

Grandchild._Child._Parent
"or even
GreatGrandchild._Grandchild._Child._Parent

 If this worked, we would need to store the reference to the parent only in the child, therefore saving space on Grandchild and Great Grandchild.

With that said, let's dive in and test this. Here I only build Parent, Child, and Grandchild.

Database tables

Parent:

@EndUserText.label : 'parent'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table z_parenttest {

  key client            : abap.clnt not null;
  key uuid              : sysuuid_x16 not null;
  local_created_by      : abp_creation_user;
  local_created_at      : abp_creation_tstmpl;
  local_last_changed_by : abp_locinst_lastchange_user;
  local_last_changed_at : abp_locinst_lastchange_tstmpl;
  last_changed_at       : abp_lastchange_tstmpl;

}

 Child:

@EndUserText.label : 'CHILD'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table z_childtest {

  key client  : abap.clnt not null;
  key uuid    : sysuuid_x16 not null;
  parent_uuid : sysuuid_x16;

}

 Grandchild:

@EndUserText.label : 'Grandchild'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table z_gchildtest {

  key client : abap.clnt not null;
  key uuid   : sysuuid_x16 not null;
  child_uuid : sysuuid_x16;

}

As you can see, the grandchild doesn't have a field for the parent's UUID.

Interface View

Parent

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'PARENT'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity ZI_PARENT
  as select from z_parenttest
  composition [0..*] of zi_child as _Child
{
  key uuid                  as Uuid,
      @Semantics.user.createdBy: true
      local_created_by      as CreatedBy,
      @Semantics.systemDateTime.createdAt: true
      local_created_at      as CreatedAt,
      @Semantics.user.lastChangedBy: true
      local_last_changed_by as LastChangedBy,
      @Semantics.systemDateTime.lastChangedAt: true
      last_changed_at       as LastChangedAt,
      @Semantics.systemDateTime.localInstanceLastChangedAt: true
      local_last_changed_at as LocalLastChangedAt,
      _Child
}

 Child

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'child'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define view entity zi_child
  as select from z_childtest
  association to parent ZI_PARENT    as _Parent on $projection.ParentUuid = _Parent.Uuid
  composition [0..*] of ZI_GRANDCHILD as _GrandChild
{
  key uuid        as Uuid,
      parent_uuid as ParentUuid,
      _Parent,
      _GrandChild
}

Everything looks normal so far. Now for what we came here for: The Grandchild!

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'GRANDE'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define view entity ZI_GRANDCHILD
  as select from z_gchildtest
  association to parent zi_child as _Child on $projection.ChildUuid = _Child.Uuid
{
  key uuid       as Uuid,
      child_uuid as ChildUuid,
      _Child,
      //You will get an error saying you have to include this
      //If you want to use _Child._Parent
      _Child.ParentUuid as ParentUUID,
      _Child._Parent as _Parent,
      
}

 And just like that, the association to parent is made, without having to store a reference.

From this point onward: Projection View, MDE, Behavior... Everything should be the same as in the mentioned blogs.

Thanks for reading my blog and I wish you a pleasant day.

entry.title: Re: ME21N copy qty from contract to PO
entry.content:
Yes in standard SAP, when you create a PO with reference to a contract, the default quantity in the PO item is normally taken from the target quantity in the contract item only if the contract is quantity‚Äëbased (target quantity maintained in the contract item), not purely value‚Äëbased, the adoption rules in customizing allow the quantity to be copied and you haven‚Äôt already got a default quantity logic in place like info record, material master, service master that overrides it.

If your contract is a service contract with UoM = KM, and you‚Äôre always getting ‚Äú1‚Äù in the PO, it usually means the contract is value‚Äëbased (target value maintained, no target quantity), so SAP can‚Äôt copy a quantity. Or, the adoption of quantity from the reference document is switched off in your copy control settings for purchasing. Or, for service POs, the system is defaulting to 1 because the service line in the service master or outline agreement has no quantity, only a limit.

entry.title: Re: Safe quantities in orders from being rescheduled?
entry.content:
Yes SAP does give you ways to ‚Äúprotect‚Äù certain sales order items from being touched by the nightly rescheduling run (SDV03V02 / V_V2), so that they keep their original confirmed quantities and dates.

Go to your sales order ‚Üí Item ‚Üí Shipping tab ‚Üí field Fix qty/date. If this flag is set, the rescheduling program will not change the confirmed quantity or date for that schedule line. Perfect for presold or ‚Äúexit‚Äù products where you want to honour the original confirmation (first‚Äëcome, first‚Äëserved).

Access Fiori apps via SAP Build Work Zone Site with Federated SAP S/4HANA Content
